title: New design photos inside the new Western Sydney International Airport at Badgerys Creek
text:
The first design photos depicting the futuristic $5.3billion Western Sydney International Airport have been revealed.

The Badgerys Creek airport won't be up and running until 2026, but the public has been given a first look at the state-of-the-art terminal.

The 1780-hectare airport site - located 50km west of the CBD - will include a modern terminal surrounded by dozens of airline gates, with two large runways.

Passengers will be able to enjoy landscaped gardens and a giant public plaza with retail shopping, dining and entertainment.

Passengers will be able to enjoy landscaped gardens and a giant public plaza with retail shopping, dining and entertainment at the $5.3billion Western Sydney International Airport (artist's impression)

The 1780-hectare airport site includes a modern terminal surrounded by dozens of airline gates, with two large runways

The interior of the terminal will feature timber ceilings and vertical growing gardens.

A team from London's Zaha Hadid Architects and Sydney's Cox Architecture designed the plans after winning the design contract for the interior.

The release of the design plans comes ahead of major earthworks which are expected to begin early next year.

This will be followed by runways, roads, rail and terminal construction.

But construction on the state-of-the-art terminal won't get started until 2022.

The Coalition called the terminal a 'once-in-a-generation infrastructure project coming to life'.

The artist's impression depicts what the new airport at Badgerys Creek - 50km west of the CBD - will look like once it's up and running in 2026

The interior of the terminal will feature timber ceilings and vertical growing gardens

'This is set to be the largest gateway to Australia and these designs are another step to making it a reality,' Prime Minister Scott Morrison said.

Cox project director David Holm said the architects were inspired by 'the unique local flora of western Sydney and the great Australian light to create an unmistakable regional identity'.

The airport will handle up to 10 million passengers per year when it opens its doors in December 2026.

But by the early 2060s the airport is expected to accommodate up to 80 million passengers annually.

Western Sydney Airport chief executive Graham Millett said that the terminal will be built for 'modular expansion due to the steadily-increasing capacity.

'The layout of the terminal will come together with technology and outstanding customer service to give passengers a reliable, fun and stress-free airport experience,' Mr Millett said.

Construction will create 11,000 new jobs in Western Sydney.

Within the first five years of opening, an extra 28,000 jobs will be generated.
